Being in the dental practice I have some skepticism behind the blanketing statement that our jaws simply aren't big enough anymore. Most African descended people have ample room in their arches for all 32 teeth, often with a central diastema. Polynesian people also often exhibit this, though not as commonly. Where in my experiences it is most often asiatic (specifically Chinese in my practice) and Caucasians that either have to have them removed or never develop them. These two broad groups of people in my experience are the ones who need between 2-8 teeth removed for orthodontic treatment. As the video stated we tend not to see maloccluded teeth in nature. This is a result of rich genetic diversity. When genetic diversity is limited due to factors such as isolation and breeding we see this readily in many animal groups, take the family friend the English bull dog as an extreme example.
Now I ask myself this is this, is this topic of malocclusion and wisdom teeth removal (or having none at all) an evolutionary leap, something that is beneficial to the human genome as a result of agriculture, or a result in loss of genetic information due to how our ancestors got jiggy with it?
I Kate the causian lean toward the side of dwindling genetic diversity.

At the head of the episode you said people "need or want to have their teeth straightened". You answered part one but didn't get at part 2, the "want" part - which is that modern humans in certain cultures place a lot of emphasis on the visual appearance of teeth. The 'crooked teeth' of an American will often be perceived as normal teeth in many other parts of the world. This leads to a much higher emphasis in certain countries or cultural spheres on attaining a certain look or arrangement of teeth, which has little to no impact on comfort or functionality outside of societal perceptions. So perception of tooth crookedness is at least partly cultural, and not genetic OR plastic.

0:51 I know this is going to sound kind of pedantic, but I really hate when science shows say things like we didn't need big jaws so our jaws shrank. That makes it sound like when we don't need things, evolution makes it go away. This encourages a very wrong understanding of evolution (which even I had until I was finishing high school). What actually happened was since you didn't need a big jaw to survive, now people with smaller/weaker jaws could survive and procreate, eventually leading to more of the population having smaller jaws over generations. It's important that we are precise when we talk about these sort of things because thinking evolution works the other way is how you get religious folk that say, "See God saw that we didn't need bigger jaws, so he let them shrink over time. How can you not see that that is intelligent design."
